segments.text: I found my name on it.
Well, the old man says, I don't know what we're going to do.
He was pulling my leg because he knew the whole story by then.
Then the... Well, what happened?
Nothing.
They just took the bomb site and left us alone.
They had us a little worried there for a week, ten days, something like that.
Then the North African invasion started.
And it had been going on, and they had been struggling down on the complete opposite end of the United Kingdom, down the land's end.
And the pirates would be in London,
Our old man up there in Prestwick said, OK, we want you to go down there and take over.
And from three different locations, we were dispatching fighters to go down and get in the act.
And this was about January, February, I guess, of 43.
And he said, OK, but I want to take

certain people with me and all right just don't just don't pull the whole outfit down because we're going to have to replace it so he i was the first 20 name he said i want you to go and so we were lucky the we he and i flew down and those enlisted personnel and the vehicles that he wanted to go down had to go by road and i don't know how much you know about the united kingdom but long about the time they got uh
Truro and kept heading south, well, road signs started disappearing and every time you'd ask, they'd ask for instructions.

Well, they may get the right instructions, they may not because the people were beginning to get leery, you know, and they didn't know whether they were Yanks or whether they were German looking like Yanks or what.
It took the convoy about a week or ten days longer than they should have just to find their way in.
But then when we did get in and got set up, it was a real good operation.
And as long as we were sending lightning down, that was all right.
Because those boys had two engines.
But any time we'd send a single engine aircraft flight down.
Down to North Africa?
Down to North Africa.
We just prayed the whole time because he had about flight time plus 10 minutes, and that's all he had.
To make the trip.
To make it, you know.
And it got pretty hairy.
Did you lose a lot of things?
Oh, yeah.
The fact is we even lost some that plotted getting to Lisbon, turn left, you know.
Never try to make it.
Just get to Lisbon and turn left.
and go on into Lisbon and finish out in the war.
As an intern in Lisbon, Portugal.
We entertained an awful lot of people coming back up.
Montgomery used to come in every once in a while.
Oh, really?
Yeah, he'd come in.
Why he would come to us, I don't know.
But he'd come to us and ask for transportation to the closest banking town, rather than go to the RAF.
And you don't know why he'd do that?
Well, see, we were still Army.
We were Army Air Corps, US type.
But he wouldn't go to the RAF.
And sure enough, we had to supply him transportation.
Let him go in and do his banking business.
Maybe provide him a place to sleep so he didn't have to go into the RAF officer's quarters the next day back to North Africa.
And what did you think of Montgomery?
What, Montgomery?
Oh, I thought he was a brilliant tactician.
Eisenhower couldn't get along with everybody.
He couldn't get along with de Gaulle either.
No, absolutely.
What do you think of the American aircraft versus the British?
The what?
American airplanes versus the British.
Well, I don't really think you can really compare them because
The British were building aircraft with their backs to the wall.
And we were still building Rolls Royce aircraft.
When the chips were down, ours came through.
But theirs came off the line a hell of a lot quicker.
And probably didn't spend as much for coffee as ours.
Our particular location, where the colonel and I were, was known as a place called Port Reef, which is a cliff about 50 yards above the sea.
And after the 17 hit the Hugo's Pen, we used to get birds back in there recovering rather than going on back to the bomber base.
It couldn't make it back.
We've actually been on a cliff and seen a B-17 deliberately come down and hit the water just so it would bounce as high as the cliff.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
No kidding?
Yeah.
Did they make it?
Sure.
Were there any that did?
None that crashed into the cliff, but some that when they did make it up there...
came on in with a gear down or something like that and then we could take whatever people were still alive and then push the bird aside.
Now why would they do that?
You mean coming in that way?
Rather than ditch?
The last thing they'd want to do is ditch out there in that cold water.
Especially if they had wounded before.
They'd have to get the wounded ashore to pick the land.
That's where we saw our first jet, but the British wouldn't let us see it.
Oh, but tell me about that.
That part of the country has always been a testing area, and since then I have been back to that particular base, and it is a closed base now.
But this must have been in late 43 before I moved on into Israel.

the London area, there was a fighter that came in and it was making a strange noise and it started taxiing down the taxiway and somebody else says, hey look at that damn thing, there's no propeller on it.
And two of us jumped in a jeep and tried to catch it and they turned in a hanger and they slammed the door on it before we could get there.
But, of course, at that time, we didn't know what the hell it was.
But it was one of their first jets.
What did it look like?
It looked like a mosquito with just chopped off, you know.
It was real small, right?
Yeah.
When you were down at Nantes Landing, were you servicing the bombers coming back and the fighters?
Our main mission was getting the fighters to North Africa and receiving the freight and passengers that were coming across the South Atlantic into our theater.
Because the organization that we were with also had
intra-theater transportation.
I see.
C-47s and Lockheed Lone Stars that the British had gotten from us and then turned back to us, and they'd fly five or six passengers, something like that.
Not much freight, but anyway, they'd outlive their usefulness on coastal patrol, and they went over to them on wind lease, and then they gave back to them.

But because we were down there and because we were U.S. forces, any of the U.S. troops that are planes that came in to recover, it was up to us to take care of them and get them back up there out there.
Were you bombed quite a bit by the Germans?
No, not down there.
Why not?
It's a long way from here.
Oh.
It's a good long way.
He got to spend that much time bombing there.
It was to his advantage to keep out to London or the industrial park, not down there, not to run in on a fighter base or something.
No, we felt relatively comfortable there.
How did you get along with the people?
I mean, not the people, not the military, British military, but just the people in the communities.
Well,
okay we lived in the we lived off base yeah they didn't have quarters for you on base well the enlisted lived on on base in what we'd call a car paper shack now but the officers lived in different
houses that had been requisitioned by the RAF, but they were spotted.
Next door would be just a British family.
But in this particular house, according to the size of it, just how many RAF and US would live.
I lived in a room with four other American officers, but down the hall there was a room with three British officers.
That was the first time that I'd ever
been exposed to, you know, they call them batmen, is a service personnel that cleans their shoes and makes up their beds and brings them tea in the morning and so on.
Well, they had bat women.
The British officers had bat women.
Well, the House would.
So they'd come in and wake us up, hand us the tea.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
That sounds like a pretty comfortable situation.
Yeah, especially those guys that were single, you know.
But some of them were pretty bad guys.
And it was there that you made major?
No, I went through that as a captain.
I made pager when I moved into the London area.
And I made pager one November 44.
Oh, okay.
Well, first, you went from second to first to captain.
A year, just every year.
A year, every year.
How can you account for that?
That's tremendous.
I guess.
I mean, you know, like...
No way of being humble.
I just say that's back to the goals that I had set.
I was going to be a military man in the period.
That was my forte.
And like I said earlier, I could see contemporaries that just didn't make it that fast.
You've got to put it somewhere.
Because it wasn't all under the same people.
I don't think I've ever had two promotions done on the same person.
What were the thoughts on the German Luftwaffe?
Do you think it was a formidable air force?
Yes.
I, my analysis or evaluation of the whole thing is just that discipline, the installation of discipline is more difficult at the top level than it is with the truth.
You can make troops realize the importance of discipline, principally for their own safety and welfare.
But you try to do that at the top, and you're going to get nothing except disbelievers.
And this is where the whole thing fell apart.
There was not discipline at the time.
I'm not talking about it in the book.
when the Luftwaffe no longer controlled the Luftwaffe, it began to just completely fall apart.
And when the decision was made to put so much emphasis into the B-1 and the B-2 and less into the Luftwaffe, he lost one of the biggest weapons the world's ever known.
Would you like something to drink?
Let's see if we can
Okay, so your duties changed in 1944 when you went to Wanda.
Is that correct?
Yeah, I became what was known as an air inspector.
It's a fancy name for inspector general.
Oh, I see.
But the Air Force or Air Corps had to be different from its Army sisters.
They called them air inspectors.
And we were then, to give you an idea, we were then a group that had been formed in the theater.
It was not formed in the United States.
Everything was put together over there.
It was equipped over there.
And we had four transport squadrons
We had two fairing squadrons.
We had a quartermaster truck company.
And we were scattered all over the United Kingdom.
The transport squadrons, they speak for themselves.
They just moved stuff within the theater.
The fairing squadrons actually...
moved the replacement aircraft from the depot up to the combat unit.
If a unit lost a bomber, our taxi aircraft, which was usually a gutted B-17 or B-24, would take crews over to the depot
They'd give them one and say, OK, take it to the building hall or wherever it was going.
And they'd deliver the aircraft.
And then the taxi would come by later and pick them up.
Well, there was a time in the war when we just lost a hell of a lot of crews.
Why?
It would beat the daylights out of them for about six months.
And we were losing them.
And we had orders from Spots headquarters that the taxi aircraft would not pick our boys up until early the next morning and then take them to the depot and let them make a run.
And our boys didn't even go back to their own base.

And what was happening was they would go and fill the empty chairs in the dining halls and drink at the bars at night, you know, and keep the places just from looking like they had just lost everything.
And so the same thing happened to
My crew and me, as we traveled around, the old man said, okay, if Tui's doing it to the pilots, you do the same thing.
Anytime you've got to move, you move in the morning and be sure that you all stay put at night.
And again, our location, we were in Ireland, back at that place that I started in Scotland, Land's End, about six or eight places in England.
And we just moved from place to place on IG inspections.
All I can say about it, it's a job.
It certainly broadens you.
Exactly what were you searching for during the inspections?
Any type of misappropriation.
misalignment or infraction of a major rule that would hurt the operation or something like that.
To wit.
Hurt the operation of the Air Force or certain airplanes?
Both.
And to wit.
The old man called me in one day and he says, over at so-and-so.
And that was where we were
loading jerrycans with gasoline, and they were flying them to the continent to pack them.
And these birds would just go back and forth.
They'd come in and land, and they'd taxi the bird right up to a pile of jerrycans, and we'd have a crew just put the jerrycans in the aircraft, and off they'd go again.
He said, okay, you get out there and find out what's going on.
He said, I've got ten suits of bastardy,
And I've got 12 A walls out there.
Get out there and find out what's going on.
Off the base, though.
Off the base, you had all these problems.
Yeah, out at this particular base where this was going on.
So I get out there and... Where was the base, do you remember?
It was a base in England.
Down near Chevelston.
I get out and I said...
Well, your first problem is you don't have a commander out here.
And he says, where's Crowley?
And I said, he's soused in the officer's club, and he's been in there three days.
And I understand from the captain out here that it's been like that for about two or three weeks.
I've had a run-in with this Major Crowley before.
I was still a captain.
I've had a run-in with him before.
And he says, OK, you stay there and take command.
And I'll get you relieved as soon as I can find somebody else to come in there.
I said, well, Colonel, I said, I can't take command, but I'll stay here and run it.
He said, why can't you?
And I said, it's listed on our chart as a flying job.
I'm not rated.
He says, when he called a captain's name, he said, oh, they're in ops.
Isn't he rated?
I said, yeah.
He says, OK. You tell him that he's in command, but stay in operations
And you get that damn gasoline thing running again.
Well, the sergeant and I had each taken out with just a musette bag, you know, just a canvas bag.
I stayed there two weeks living out of that canvas bag until he got another major.
He got a major down there.
He relieved this guy and finally sent him on back to the States.
But it was a...

just a round-the-clock operation because the logistics department who was stretching his line was such that he couldn't bring it up from his rear and we had to always just meet him as he was making his dash across the country.
So he'd make his dash and he'd tell you what airstrip that he wants your planes at at a certain time.
With how much oil or as much gas as you could get to them?
The tank ran on the same fuel that our birds ran on.
Oh, okay.
And so you'd meet them in a certain place at a certain time.
That's right.
And you'd just keep up with them all the time.
Was it easy or hard to work with?
Who, me?
Yeah.
Fortunately, I didn't have to communicate with them.
All I had to do was get the damn birds loaded and ready for the ops to say,
A-40 or C-69 or wherever they were headed.
Were a lot of your airplanes shot down?
No.
I guess the reason that they weren't is our old man was a pretty outspoken guy and he had his way.
Les Arnold
And that doesn't mean anything to you, but Les was the vice president of Eastern Airlines when he went back on active duty for World War II.
But he was also one of the crew that made the first round-the-world flight in the Douglas aircraft.
You know, the open cockpit job?
He was one of those guys.
And he just told Fox, don't send me the C-46s.
I won't fly them.
Well, the C-46 carried a hell of a lot more weight than the C-47.
But unfortunately, all of its hydraulics were in a very critical area right down the belly underneath.
And a guy with a rifle could put the damn thing out.
And we proved it by the first one that came over there.
And he just turned them down.
And so what we were really using
to carry the cans back and forth were ripped out B-17s and B-24s, which had a, boy, they'd fly on a prairie.
Yeah.
So you'd use bombers then for transports.
That's right.
Just clean out all the innards.
Cleaned out everything.
But they were birds that had gone back to the depot, and the depot was a, you know,
It'd be more economic, or rather than rebuild it back to the mom state, let's use them for this.
We didn't have the authority to rip them out, but we didn't have any trouble with it that far.
But Les was fantastic.
He was of that age group and that

and had the rapport with the the top air force people because of his position with eastern and even though he was just a colonel and he you know he just talked to him like you can't do that to it you know i've heard him on the phone where any other colonel would probably been crucified you know but there were a number of people like that that were brought back into the war see rickenbacker let him leave eastern
Rickenbacker was then president of Eastern.
He let him leave Eastern just to come back in during the war, because they needed people like that.
Were there any other problems that you were having as far as Air Inspector?
Any other major problems?
Well, the next problem I had was a personal problem.
It took me out of duty for a while.
developed some symptoms that they couldn't determine what the hell was the matter with me and I consented to an exploratory and they removed 14 inches of my small intestines and
gave me a choice as to whether I'd come home or go back to duty, and I went back to duty.
Didn't make the little gal downstairs happy, but still.
Ain't no sense in going back and getting started somewhere else, because it's been the same thing all over, because everybody's coming home for 30 days, and then, whop, right back over.
So I just said, well, let's go.
As soon as I came out of the hospital, I went right back to my same outfit because personnel people had the way paved through the depot that I wasn't about to go to another outfit.
I was going right back to the same outfit.
They made me a station agent.
I was promoted to major.
Les' headquarters was at a great big white mansion which was about two miles off of the RAF base that we kept all our aircraft at.
This was at a base called RAF Heston.
RAF Heston is now in the approach zone of
Heathrow, which is the big airport in London.
So it has been swallowed up by the base.
But that's where it was.
And that put it right straight in Buzz Bomb Alley.
And that's where we, though we didn't suffer any

death casualties we did suffer injuries and a lot of physical damage at the base and we were well pretty fortunate that Les Arnold's headquarters was not on the base it was back off though it could have been hit it had its own communication system and everything but I went by one thing that
that was really interesting and to show you that no matter who you are, you can always do something different.
The night before D-Day, we had, and of course this was even before this jerrycan thing, the fly in the gasoline.
Oh, absolutely.
Yeah, somewhere in there.
But the night before, the U.S. Air Corps changed the symbols on all of its airplanes.
I don't know whether you were aware of that or not, but we used to have just a star and a circle.
And the night before,
put the star with the big rectangle box out to each side.
Why was that?
Because there were so many of our birds down in Europe and being used by Jerry that they wanted a definite identity of what was ours and what wasn't ours.
And all over the United Kingdom,
All the bomber bases, the fighter bases, the transport bases, every aircraft we had that night had the new symbol put on them.
That took every enlisted man and every officer.
And boy, all we did all night long was just paint those new symbols on the birds.
And of course, it paid off.
They tried to put some into our formations over the beaches and things like that.
In other words, their symbol could be changed, or our old symbol could be changed too easily to their symbol?
No, they were flying ours.
They were flying our symbol.
They were flying our birds as though they were peaceful, and then bombing us or strafing us.
I see, I see.
So they'd get a hold of ours that went down, repair them, and then fly ours.
That's right.
I see.
They'd fly them across North Scotland or down in the mid or something like that.
Anywhere.
And they'd look like ours.
That's right.
So did we have a big problem with that?
We had a big problem with that.
Well, there was enough of it that...
Somebody in Eisenhower's staff said, we want them changed.
We changed them so that when we hit the beaches, we'll know which are ours.
We'll fire on all the old ones and let the new ones come on through.
So the night before, all over the United Kingdom, we were changing that outside symbol.
And on D-Day, were you involved in any way?
On D-Day, just there at the base of sending out the transports and sending people down into the area where the troops were going from.
But I did not go into the beach or anything.
I didn't go into Cherbourg until, I went into Cherbourg about three days after Cherbourg was taken.
And we established our first point there of freight
being moved by our aircraft in the Cherbourg.
And then the next point that I moved into was into Paris.
But at Cherbourg it was basically move in as much military supplies as fast as possible.
Flying the essentials.
Everything else still came in by boat and by lighter.
But the essentials were flown in.
Medical supplies, ammunition, stuff like that?
No, ammunition.
We didn't fly anything.
What did you fly in?
Parts.
Mechanical parts.
And were you flying the old bombers or were you flying anything?
Anything that we had.
Most of, by that time, the
we were pretty well equipped with C-47.
And what was your job, Sherbert?
I went in and established the layout of the camp and stayed in there until they got the things set up, and then I came on back.
And then I went in and did the same thing.
Somebody else was in charge of that.
And then I did the same thing, and when they liberated Paris, I went in
I made the assessment on what we had to do to Le Bourget.
Le Bourget is where Lindbergh landed and had just been bombed to hell.
They told us that we were going to have to operate out of Le Bourget because the inner theater aircraft, the big transports, were going to work from Orly to the other airports.
Another officer now went in and made the assessment.
What's the difference now?
I'm not quite clear on that.
What do you mean the other aircraft were going to...
The inter-theater from Paris back to the United States.
Oh, okay.
The big, which is now MAC.
We were strictly theater.
Okay, okay.
And they, by the time we knew that we...
That's not a good statement.
I was going to say, by the time we knew we had Paris, we didn't know that for quite a while.
But anyway, the plan was that we would start bypassing the United Kingdom.
You want to light on it?
No.
Oh, no.
But we'd bypass the United Kingdom so you can start working straight to the continent.
Uh-huh.
And so they got orally.
And we got one on the other side of town.
OK, so any Washington or New York to Paris, then they go straight into Orland.
Into Orland.
OK. And the big general hospital was set right out about three miles from Orland, so that it could be very back to the state.
But working strictly in Tron Theater, we got the other side of town.
And the conditions there were all bombs.
Oh, yeah.

fact is how did the germans do this before they allowed to no no we did it we did it and then had to go in and sometimes we're foolish but then we had to go in and bulldoze it over and or just ignore part of their buttons but i went to an air show there and but your job was to clean it up right my job was to go and make the assessment as to what
we would have to do to use Leborger.
You know, and how much engineering effort we had to get to get the rubble out of the way, and how much runway we'd have to have repaired, and so on.
Well, they carried part.
We did.
I mean, we went in.
Hell, we had to get in.
You know, all it was was not whether, can you use this?
What's the effort to use it?
Because it being...
communication center.
There was no way that we could operate in the theater unless we were in there.
Now our headquarters by that time we had grown from the 27th Air Transport Group had been joined with the 31st and it was now the 302nd Transport Wing.
So that made it
about twice the size, not completely, but about twice the size that we had before then.
Because the 31st came up from the southern, from the belly through Italy and coming up that way.
And then they joined them together.
And the 302nd Transport Wing headquarters was located in downtown Paris after we had moved into Le Bourget and they had moved on up the country.
But I said a while ago, after we had felt that we had Paris, when the general told the Germans nuts at Bastogne, had Bastogne fallen, then everybody that was at Compigne would have moved to Paris.
And everybody that was in Paris would have either moved south in France or back to the United Kingdom.
And we were already packed to go back to the United Kingdom.
This was our order, you know.
Had the dominoes started falling, because... You were going to make a strategic retreat.
Well, we had to make room for everybody else.
But fortunately, it didn't come about.
And Compigne held, which was the advance...
headquarters and Paris was the logistical support headquarters.
But that was not a very happy Christmas because a number of us knew what was about to happen.
Let's get back to Paris now.
You went in there and when was this?
About September of 1944?
October?
Right after it was liberated?
Yes.
Okay.
And at that time I was
the director of personnel of the 300 second transport wing, as well as the agent general of the wing.
And to give you an idea, that's 1,000 officers, 5,000 enlisted, and 1,500 civilians.
But again, remember that spread, United Kingdom, France,
all the way down to southern France.
We didn't have anybody in Italy, but we were all through France and all through the United Kingdom.
It was a table of organization that was crazy when it was based, the way administration can get screwed up, it was based on a table of organization equipment that was put together
for the HUP in India.
And TO had six officers authorized, and we had 36 officers.
Any time you do that, all you do is you rob 30 authorizations from your subordinates.
And it makes promotions pretty damn rough.
I was sitting there as a major in the lieutenant colonel's slot.
What a way in the world to get promoted.
So everything is eaten up, you know.
Then they started holding us to authorization.
Now, can you tell me about the conditions in Paris?
You must have gone into Paris.
And about the people, how they treated you.
Well, the Parisians
There are French people and there are Parisians.
The Frenchman, individually, is one of the nicest guys that I think you'll ever want to know.
Collectively, they're a bunch of milk hounds.
They get, we were talking about spirit and emotion earlier.
They get all wrapped up and they're just too damn easy to get let off on the wrong track or something like that.
We had no problems with them because, again, we were the big liberators and a lot of them knew it even though we sat back and a number of units like us were in there, no big
U.S. unit with great big generals came in until after De Gaulle did.
De Gaulle made the sweep into Paris and took all of the glory and everything.
Even though we had units already in there.
They didn't put generals in to make parades and claim the victory.
They let De Gaulle come in.
But the Frenchmen knew who were in there.
Because
At that time, de Gaulle still didn't have France completely under his wings.
He was still a little questionable.
We had some misgivings with
some of their military are owning it.
We lived in a fabulous, the officers lived in a fabulous big house out on the edge of the border balloon, which is the fashionable part of Paris.
And directly across the street from the Gauls residence.
And every once in a while,

security would get a little concerned about our conduct or what was going on and come over and try to quiet us down or something like that and so our provost marshal was always having to remind them that when they crossed the threshold they were in u.s territory not in france you know and he spoke pretty good french and he managed to communicate with him i guess the worst time that we ever had with him was
We got up on top of our building and started cutting off the submachine gun and the .45s because we didn't have any firecrackers.
That really put a security force into activity, but we lived through it.
So would you consider then that the relations between the French and the American soldiers, as far as you knew, were rather strained?
No.
Friendly?
Oh, they were friendly, sure.
We're just in an isolated situation here where if I was guarding the galleys, it would scare the hell out of me, too.
Sure.
Absolutely.
This same lieutenant named Carter from Boston, Massachusetts, he was a subordinate of mine and was a provost marshal.
And he was out one day and he found a marshaling yard that
had a huge supply of coal.
And it was the size of coal that you would use in a boiler, like on a locomotive or even in a heating plant.
And he came back and reported it to me.
And I immediately told the old man about it.
And he called the chief of staff in.
And the chief of staff was Colonel Henry Bevelle.
And he said, OK, Henry.
you'll take half of the officers and half the enlisted men tomorrow, and Hub, you'll take the other half the next day, and we're going to move that coat.
And so Henry went out with his half, and I went out the next day with my half, and then when Henry went back out the next day, it was run by military police.
So we only got two days haul of coal out of there.
But we had officers and men hauling coal like they came out of West Virginia because coal was in real short supply.
And just what we got kicked to our supply.
Saw us through the winter comfortably.
Oh, man.
And the enlisted men too.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
And then the French military police went on?
Oh, the U.S. military police.
Oh, the U.S. military police.
But they didn't make you bring back the... No, no, they didn't know.
They didn't know.
They might have known, but there was no way they were going to make us bring it back.
All they were doing was just protecting it for the supply people then.
We didn't figure the supply people had any more title to it than we did.
It was a bombed-out railroad yard, but...
Well, anyway, it was from that headquarters that Colonel Angel, that we had referred to earlier, had been the administrative assistant to the president at A&M.
